revision.comment: Updating URL format for [[The New York Times]]
revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1914 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Army Black Knights|Army Cadets]] '''Professional championships''' * [[Ohio League|Ohio League champions]] – [[Akron Pros|Akron Parratt's Indians]] '''Events''' * 15 November — [[Harry Turner (American football)|Harry Turner]], of the [[Canton Bulldogs|Canton Professionals]], becomes the first player to die from game-related injuries in the "Ohio League", the direct predecessor to the [[National Football League]].
==[[Association football]]== '''Brazil''' * Formation of the [[Brazilian Football Confederation]] (Confederação Brasileira de Futebol or CBF) * [[Sociedade Esportiva Palmeiras]] officially founded in [[São Paulo]] on August 26.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} '''England''' * [[1913–14 Football League|The Football League]] – [[Blackburn Rovers]] 51 points, [[Aston Villa]] 44, [[Middlesbrough FC|Middlesbrough]] 43, [[Oldham Athletic]] 43, [[West Bromwich Albion]] 43, [[Bolton Wanderers]] 42 * [[1914 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Burnley FC|Burnley]] 1–0 [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at [[Crystal Palace National Sports Centre|Crystal Palace]], London '''Germany''' * [[List of German football champions|National Championship]] – [[SpVgg Fürth]] (2–2) 3–2 [[VfB Leipzig]] at Magdeburg '''Portugal''' * Formation in [[Lisbon]] of the [[Portuguese Football Federation]] (Federação Portuguesa de Futebol or FPF) '''Scotland''' * [[Scottish Football League]] – [[Glasgow Celtic|Celtic]] * [[1914 Scottish Cup Final|Scottish Cup final]] – [[Glasgow Celtic|Celtic]] 4–1 [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] at [[Ibrox Stadium|Ibrox Park]] (replay following 0–0 draw)
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''[[1914 VFL season|VFL Premiership]]''' * 26 September – [[Carlton Football Club|Carlton]] wins the 18th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership, defeating [[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne]] 6.9 (45) to 4.15 (39) in the [[1914 VFL Grand Final]] '''[[South Australian National Football League|South Australian Football League]]''' * 19 September – [[Port Adelaide Magpies|Port Adelaide]] 13.15 (93) defeats [[North Adelaide Football Club|North Adelaide]] 1.8 (14) for their second successive SAFL flag and eighth overall * [[Magarey Medal]] won by [[Jack Ashley (footballer)|Jack Ashley]] (Port Adelaide) '''[[West Australian Football League]]''' * 10 October – [[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]] 5.13 (43) defeats [[South Fremantle Football Club|South Fremantle]] 3.6 (24) for its ninth WAFL premiership. '''Events''' * [[Melbourne University Football Club|University]] withdraws from the VFL at the end of the season * Port Adelaide become the only SAFA/SAFL/SANFL team to finish with a [[perfect season]], overall winning thirty consecutive matches including one against a combined team from the other six SAFL clubs and one against Carlton.<ref>Devaney, John; [http://australianfootball.com/articles/view/The%2BInvincibles%2Bat%2Bplay%2B-%2BSAFL%2BRnd%2B8%2B1914%253A%2BPort%2BAdelaide%2Bv%2BSouths/16 ‘The Invincibles at Play’]</ref>
==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Allsvenskan and Elitserien (bandy)|Championship final]] – [[AIK Bandy|AIK]] 4–2 [[Djurgårdens IF Bandy|Djurgårdens IF]]
==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 9–13 October — [[Boston Braves (baseball)|Boston Braves]] (NL) defeats [[Oakland Athletics|Philadelphia Athletics]] (AL) to win the [[1914 World Series]] by 4 games to 0 '''Events''' * The "Federal League War" ensues when the Federal League leaves [[Minor League Baseball]] and competes with the two established major leagues. Retaining clubs in Kansas City, Indianapolis, St Louis, Chicago and Pittsburgh, the Federal League sets up additional clubs in Buffalo, Baltimore and Brooklyn. * [[Baltimore Terrapins]] are a great popular success and drive the minor [[Baltimore Orioles (minor league)|Orioles]] out of business, so creating the basis of the baseball anti–trust case * 22 April — [[Babe Ruth]] pitches his first professional game for the [[Baltimore Orioles (minor league)|Baltimore Orioles]] at age 19
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * [[Jack Johnson (boxer)|Jack Johnson]] spends the year moving from one country to another but stages exhibition fights as far afield as [[Gothenburg]] and [[Buenos Aires]]. In June, he defends his world heavyweight title against [[Frank Moran]] in Paris and wins over 20 rounds. * 1 to 24 January — Danish boxer Waldemar Holberg defeats Ray Bronson over 20 rounds in [[Melbourne]] and claims the vacant [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship. Just 23 days later, Holberg loses the title to Tom McCormick after a sixth round foul, also at Melbourne. * 21 March — McCormick loses the welterweight title to [[Matt Wells (boxer)|Matt Wells]] over 20 rounds at [[Sydney]]. * 30 March — a [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship (108 lb to 112 lb) is proposed for the first time after [[Jimmy Wilde]] defeats Eugene Husson in London. Wilde, subsequently ranked by most experts as the greatest-ever flyweight, holds the title until 1923. * 7 April — [[Al McCoy (boxer)|Al McCoy]] defeats [[George Chip]] with a surprise first round knockout in [[Brooklyn]], New York, to take the [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship. McCoy holds the title until 1917. * With a series of wins from April to November, [[Jack Dillon]] resolves the long-standing issue of the vacant [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship in his favour. He defeats [[Battling Levinsky]], [[Bob Moha]], Frank Mantell and Charley Weinert to claim the title, which he holds until 1916. * 3 June — [[Kid Williams]] defeats [[Johnny Coulon]] by a third round knockout at Vernon, California, to win the [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship. Williams holds the title until 1917. * 7 July — [[Freddie Welsh]] defeats [[Willie Ritchie]] over 20 rounds in London to win the [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship. Welsh holds the title until 1917. '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Johnson (boxer)|Jack Johnson]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – vacant → [[Jack Dillon]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[George Chip]] → [[Al McCoy (boxer)|Al McCoy]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – vacant → Waldemar Holberg → Tom McCormick → [[Matt Wells (boxer)|Matt Wells]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Willie Ritchie]] → [[Freddie Welsh]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Kilbane]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Coulon]] → [[Kid Williams]] * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jimmy Wilde]]
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * [[6th Grey Cup]] – [[Toronto Argonauts]] 14–2 [[University of Toronto Varsity Blues]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * The [[1914 English cricket season]] is cancelled at the end of August because of the outbreak of the [[First World War]]. The last four matches to be played all finish on 2 September and the remaining five scheduled fixtures are cancelled. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Surrey CCC|Surrey]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – ''undecided'' * Most runs – [[Jack Hobbs]] 2697 @ 58.63 (HS 226) * Most wickets – [[Colin Blythe]] 170 @ 15.19 (BB 9–97) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] – [[Johnny Douglas]], [[Percy Fender]], [[Wally Hardinge]], [[Donald Knight (cricketer)|Donald Knight]], [[Sydney Smith (cricketer)|Sydney Smith]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[New South Wales cricket team|New South Wales]] * Most runs – [[Charlie Macartney]] 892 @ 111.50 (HS 201) * Most wickets – [[Charles Kelleway]] 45 @ 12.68 (BB 7–35) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular]] – [[Hindus cricket team|Hindus]] shared with [[Muslims cricket team|Muslims]] '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – [[Canterbury cricket team|Canterbury]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – ''not contested'' '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – ''not contested''
==[[Cycling]]== '''Tour de France''' * [[Philippe Thys]] (Belgium) wins the 12th [[List of Tour de France winners|Tour de France]]
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Men's Champion]] – Gosta Sandahl (Sweden) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Women's Champion]] – Opika von Méray Horváth (Hungary) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Pairs Champions]] – Ludowika Jakobsson-Eilers / Walter Jakobsson (Finland)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1914 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Harry Vardon]] * [[1914 U.S. Open (golf)|US Open]] – [[Walter Hagen]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – J L C Jenkins * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[Francis Ouimet]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1914 Grand National|Grand National]] – Sunloch * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Princess Dorrie]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Kennymore]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Durbar (horse)|Durbar]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Princess Dorrie * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Black Jester]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Kingsburgh '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Beehive '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Civil War * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Land of Song '''USA''' * [[1914 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Old Rosebud * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Holiday * [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[Luke McLuke]]
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * [[Toronto Blueshirts]] wins the [[National Hockey Association]] (NHA) championship and their first [[Stanley Cup]]. '''Events''' * [[Victoria Aristocrats]] wins the [[Pacific Coast Hockey Association]] (PCHA) championship * Blueshirts play Aristocrats in a challenge series with Blueshirts winning by three games to nil. The NHA and PCHA agree to start an annual playoff in 1915 to decide the Stanley Cup winner. * Regina Victorias wins the [[1914 Allan Cup|Allan Cup]]
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1914 in motorsport}}
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 28 March — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 71st [[The Boat Race|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''International''' *[[1914 Great Britain Lions tour of Australia and New Zealand]] '''England''' * [[Rugby Football League Championship|Championship]] – [[Salford Red Devils|Salford]] * [[Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup final]] – [[Hull F.C.]] 6–0 [[Wakefield Trinity]] at [[Thrum Hall]], [[Halifax, West Yorkshire|Halifax]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – [[Huddersfield Giants|Huddersfield]] * [[RFL Lancashire Cup|Lancashire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Oldham R.L.F.C.|Oldham]] 5–0 [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] * [[RFL Yorkshire Cup|Yorkshire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Huddersfield Giants|Huddersfield]] 19–3 [[Bradford Bulls|Bradford Northern]] '''Australia''' * [[New South Wales Rugby League premiership|NSW Premiership]] – [[South Sydney Rabbitohs|South Sydney]] (outright winner) '''New Zealand''' *[[1914 New Zealand rugby league season]]
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Five Nations Championship''' * 32nd [[Six Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is won by [[England national rugby union team|England]] who complete the [[Grand Slam (rugby union)|Grand Slam]]
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[1915 World Allround Speed Skating Championships|Men's All-round Champion]] – [[Oscar Mathisen]] (Norway)
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Arthur O'Hara Wood]] (Australia) defeats [[Gerald Patterson]] (Australia) 6–4 6–3 5–7 6–1 '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Norman Brookes]] (Australia) defeats [[Anthony Wilding]] (New Zealand) 6–4 6–4 7–5 * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Dorothea Douglass Lambert Chambers]] defeats [[Ethel Thomson Larcombe]] 7–5 6–4 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Max Decugis]] defeats [[Jean Samazeuilh]] 3–6 6–1 6–4 6–4 * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Marguerite Broquedis]] defeats [[Suzanne Lenglen]] 5–7 6–4 6–3 '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Richard Norris Williams]] defeats [[Maurice McLoughlin]] 6–3 8–6 10–8 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Mary Browne]] defeats [[Marie Wagner]] 6–2 1–6 6–1 '''Davis Cup''' * [[1914 International Lawn Tennis Challenge]] – {{davis|Australasia}} 3–2 {{davis|USA|1912}} at [[West Side Tennis Club]] (grass) [[New York City]], [[United States]]
==[[Yacht racing]]== * [[1914 America's Cup]] – ''[[Resolute (yacht)|Resolute]]'' competes against the ''[[Vanitie]]'' but the race is cancelled due to the onset of [[World War I]].<ref name=hustle>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Resolute Beats All Cup Course Records. Shamrock Will Have to Hustle to Better Yesterday's Time. 30 Miles in 3:16:41 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1914/06/11/archives/resolute-beats-all-cup-course-records-shamrock-will-have-to-hustle.html |quote=The flag officers' sloop Resolute covered herself with much seafoam and more glory in her first race over the America's Cup course off Sandy Hook yesterday. She not only left her chief rival, Vanitie, far astern, but set such a hot pace in the fifteen-mile thrash to windward and back that she broke all previous records for the thirty-mile cup course. ... Selah B. Howell, her professional sailing master, Resolute's rig consisted of mainsail, and single headsail, and each canvas fitted smooth as a glove. ... |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 11, 1914 |accessdate=2010-10-15 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1901 – 1950}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1914 in sports| ]]

revision.comment: /* [[Rugby league]] */clean up, replaced: [[York Wasps|York]] → [[York City Knights|York]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1931 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Alpine skiing]]== '''FIS Alpine World Ski Championships'''
Inaugural [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 1931|FIS Alpine World Ski Championships]] are held at [[Mürren]], Switzerland. The events are a [[Downhill (ski competition)|downhill]] and a [[Slalom skiing|slalom]] race in both the men's and women's categories. The winners are: * Men's Downhill – [[Walter Prager]] (Switzerland) * Men's Slalom – [[David Zogg]] (Switzerland) * Women's Downhill – [[Esme Mackinnon]] (Great Britain) * Women's Slalom – [[Esme Mackinnon]] (Great Britain)
==[[American football]]== * [[1931 Green Bay Packers season|Green Bay Packers]] win [[1931 NFL season|the NFL title]] with a 13–2 record * [[Rose Bowl Game|Rose Bowl]] (1930 season): ** The [[Alabama Crimson Tide football|Alabama Crimson Tide]] won 24-0 over [[Washington State Cougars football|the Washington State Cougars]] to share the college football national championship
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[1930–31 Football League|The Football League]] – [[Arsenal FC|Arsenal]] 66 points, [[Aston Villa]] 59, [[Sheffield Wednesday]] 52, [[Portsmouth FC|Portsmouth]] 49, [[Huddersfield Town]] 48, [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] 46 * [[1931 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[West Bromwich Albion]] 2–1 [[Birmingham City]] at [[Wembley Stadium (1924)|Empire Stadium, Wembley, London]] '''Germany''' * [[1931 German football championship|National Championship]] – [[Hertha BSC]] 3–2 [[TSV 1860 München]] at Köln '''Spain''' * [[1930–31 La Liga|La Liga]] won by [[Athletic Bilbao]] '''Italy''' * [[1930–31 Serie A|Serie A]] won by [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] '''Brazil''' * Foundation of [[Botafogo Futebol Clube (PB)|Botafogo Rio]]
==[[Australian rules football]]== * May 9: [[Richmond Football Club|Richmond]] beat [[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne]]’s 12 year record for the highest score when they kick 30.19 (199) to [[North Melbourne Football Club|North Melbourne]]’s 4.7 (31). [[Doug Strang]], in his second game, and [[Jack Titus]] kick 22 goals between them – still an equal record for two players on one side. '''[[1931 VFL season|VFL Premiership]]''' * [[Geelong Football Club|Geelong]] wins the 35th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership: defeating Richmond 9.14 (68) to 7.6 (48) at [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] (MCG) * The annual [[Brownlow Medal]] is awarded to [[Haydn Bunton, Sr|Haydn Bunton senior]] ([[Fitzroy Football Club|Fitzroy]]) '''[[South Australian National Football League]]''' * 3 October: [[North Adelaide Football Club|North Adelaide]] 17.13 (115) defeat [[Sturt Football Club|Sturt]] 11.11 (77) to win their sixth SANFL premiership. * [[Magarey Medal]] won by [[Jack Sexton]] ([[West Adelaide Football Club|West Adelaide]]) '''[[1931 WANFL season|Western Australian National Football League]]''' * 1 June: [[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]]’s 4.28 (52) against [[South Fremantle Football Club|South Fremantle]]’s 5.8 (38) is the second most inaccurate score in WA(N)FL history by excess of behinds over goals and the most until 1957.<ref>[http://australianfootball.com/seasons/inaccurate_scoring/WAFL_129 West Australian Football League: Most Inaccurate Scores]</ref> * 17 October: East Fremantle win their fourth consecutive WA(N)FL premiership, beating [[Subiaco Football Club|Subiaco]] 9.13 (67) to 7.7 (49) in the [[1931 WANFL Grand Final]]. * [[Sandover Medal]] won by [[Lin Richards]] ([[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]])
==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Swedish bandy champions|Championship final]] – [[AIK Bandy|AIK]] 4–3 IF Karlstad-Göta
==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 1–10 October — [[1931 St. Louis Cardinals season|St. Louis Cardinals]] (NL) defeats [[1931 Philadelphia Athletics season|Philadelphia Athletics]] (AL) to win the [[1931 World Series]] by four games to three '''Major League Baseball''' * MVP awards to [[Frankie Frisch]] (NL) and [[Lefty Grove]] (AL) '''Negro League Baseball''' * The [[Negro National League (1920–1931)|Negro National League]] disbands. [[St. Louis Stars (baseball)|St. Louis Stars]] win the last championship.
==[[Basketball]]== '''ABL Championship'''
*[[Brooklyn Visitations]] win four games to two over the [[Fort Wayne Hoosiers]]
'''College Championship''' * [[Northwestern Wildcats men's basketball|Northwestern University]] wins the men's college basketball title
'''Events''' *The ABL suspends operations after the 1930–1931 season. This is also the last year it operates as a major professional league.
==[[Bobsleigh]]== '''Bobsleigh World Championships''' * 2nd [[FIBT World Championships 1931]] are held in [[Oberhof, Germany|Oberhof]], Germany (two-man bob) and [[St Moritz]], Switzerland (four-man bob). Both gold medals are won by Germany.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * [[World Middleweight Champion]] [[Mickey Walker (boxer)|Mickey Walker]] vacates his title to campaign as a heavyweight. The middleweight championship remains vacant until 1941. '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Max Schmeling]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Maxie Rosenbloom]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Mickey Walker (boxer)|Mickey Walker]] → vacant * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – Tommy Freeman → "Young" Jack Thompson → [[Lou Brouillard]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Tony Canzoneri]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – Bat Battalino * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Panama Al Brown]] * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – vacant
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * [[19th Grey Cup]] in the [[Canadian Football League]] – [[Montreal AAA]] defeats [[Regina Roughriders]] 22–0
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]] plays its first [[Test cricket|Test series]] in England. [[England national cricket team|England]] wins the series 1–0 with two matches drawn. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|Yorkshire]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – [[Leicestershire County Cricket Club|Leicestershire II]] * Most runs – [[Herbert Sutcliffe]] 3006 @ 96.96 (HS 230) * Most wickets – [[Tich Freeman]] 276 @ 15.60 (BB 10–79) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] – [[Bill Bowes]], [[Stewie Dempster]], [[James Langridge]], [[Iftikhar Ali Khan Pataudi]], [[Hedley Verity]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[Victoria cricket team|Victoria]] * Most runs – [[Don Bradman]] 1422 @ 79.00 (HS 258) * Most wickets – [[Clarrie Grimmett]] 74 @ 19.14 (BB 7–87) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular]] – ''not contested'' '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – [[Canterbury cricket team|Canterbury]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – ''not contested'' '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – ''not contested''
==[[Cycling]]== '''Tour de France''' * [[Antonin Magne]] (France) wins the 25th [[1931 Tour de France|Tour de France]] '''Other events''' * [[1930 Giro d'Italia|Giro d'Italia]] is won by [[Francesco Camusso]] (Italy) * [[World Cycling Championship]] is won by [[Learco Guerra]] (Italy)
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Men's Champion]] – [[Karl Schäfer]] (Austria) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Women's Champion]] – [[Sonja Henie]] (Norway) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Pairs Champions]] – [[Emília Rotter]] and [[László Szollás]] (Hungary)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1931 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Tommy Armour]] * [[1931 U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] – [[Billy Burke (golfer)|Billy Burke]] * [[1931 PGA Championship|PGA Championship]] – [[Tom Creavy]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – Eric Martin-Smith * [[U.S. Amateur]] – [[Francis Ouimet]] * [[Women's Western Open]] – [[June Beebe]]
==[[Harness racing]]== '''USA''' * [[Hambletonian Stakes|Hambletonian]] – Calumet Butler * [[Kentucky Futurity]] – The Protector
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[Champion Hurdle]] – ''not contested due to frost'' * [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] – ''not contested due to frost'' * [[1931 Grand National|Grand National]] – Grakle * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Four Course]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Cameronian (horse)|Cameronian]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – Cameronian * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Brulette]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Sandwich (horse)|Sandwich]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – White Nose '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Froth Blower '''France''' * [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] – [[Pearl Cap]] '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Impudent Barney * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Sea Serpent '''USA''' * [[1931 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – [[Twenty Grand]] * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Mate * [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[Twenty Grand]]
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * [[1930–31 Montreal Canadiens season|Montreal Canadiens]] defeats [[1930–31 Chicago Black Hawks season|Chicago Black Hawks]] by 3 games to 2 '''Ice Hockey World Championships''' * Gold Medal – [[Canada men's national ice hockey team|Canada]] * Silver Medal – [[United States men's national ice hockey team|United States]] * Bronze Medal – [[Austria men's national ice hockey team|Austria]] '''Other events''' * ''[[Hockey Night in Canada]]'', now the oldest sports-related television program still on air, debuts as a radio program known as the ''General Motors Hockey Broadcast''. The TV series begins in 1952.
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1931 in motorsport|List of 1931 motorsport champions}}
==[[Nordic skiing]]== '''FIS Nordic World Ski Championships''' * 6th [[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 1931]] are held at [[Oberhof, Germany|Oberhof]], Germany
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 21 March — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 83rd [[The Boat Race 1931|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''England''' * [[Rugby Football League Championship|Championship]] – [[Swinton Lions|Swinton]] * [[Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup final]] – [[Halifax R.L.F.C.|Halifax]] 22–8 [[York City Knights|York]] at [[Wembley Stadium (1924)|Empire Stadium, Wembley, London]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – [[Swinton Lions|Swinton]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – [[Leeds Rhinos|Leeds]] * [[RFL Lancashire Cup|Lancashire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[St Helens Recreation RLFC|St Helens Recs]] 18–3 [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] * [[RFL Yorkshire Cup|Yorkshire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Leeds Rhinos|Leeds]] 10–2 [[Huddersfield Giants|Huddersfield]] '''Australia''' * [[New South Wales Rugby League premiership|NSW Premiership]] – [[South Sydney Rabbitohs|South Sydney]] 12–7 [[Sydney Roosters|Eastern Suburbs]]
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Five Nations Championship''' * 44th [[1931 Five Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is won by [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]] * Shortly after the 1931 Five Nations Championship is completed, [[France national rugby union team|France]] is banned from the competition due to allegations of professionalism and administrative deficiencies. France will be readmitted after the [[1939 Home Nations Championship|1939 competition]] but will not be able to play until [[1947 Five Nations Championship|1947]] because of the suspension of international rugby during [[World War II]]. In the meantime, the competition reverts to its original title of Home Nations Championship.
==[[Snooker]]== '''World Championship''' * 5th [[1931 World Snooker Championship|World Snooker Championship]] is won by [[Joe Davis]] who defeats [[Tom Dennis (snooker player)|Tom Dennis]] 25–21
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[World Allround Speed Skating Championships for Men|Men's All-round Champion]] – [[Clas Thunberg]] (Finland)
==[[Tennis]]== {{main|1931 in tennis}} '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Jack Crawford (tennis player)|Jack Crawford]] (Australia) defeats [[Harry Hopman]] (Australia) 6–4 6–2 2–6 6–1 * [[List of Australian Open Women's Singles champions|Australian Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Coral Buttsworth]] (Australia) defeats [[Marjorie Cox Crawford]] (Australia) 1–6 6–3 6–4 '''England''' * [[List of Wimbledon Gentlemen's Singles champions|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Sidney Wood]] (USA) by a walkover after [[Frank Shields]] (USA) withdraws from the final due to an ankle injury * [[List of Wimbledon Ladies' Singles champions|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Cilly Aussem]] (Germany) defeats [[Hilde Krahwinkel Sperling]] (Germany) 6–2 7–5 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Jean Borotra]] (France) defeats [[Christian Boussus]] (USA) 2–6 6–4 7–5 6–4 * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Cilly Aussem]] (Germany) defeats [[Betty Nuthall]] (Great Britain) 8–6 6–1 '''USA''' * [[List of US Open Men's Singles champions|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Ellsworth Vines]] (USA) defeats [[George Lott]] (USA) 7–9 6–3 9–7 7–5 * [[List of US Open Women's Singles champions|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Helen Wills Moody]] (USA) defeats [[Eileen Bennett Whittingstall]] (Great Britain) 6–4 6–1 '''Davis Cup''' * [[1931 International Lawn Tennis Challenge]] – {{davis|FRA}} 3–2 {{davis|GBR}} at [[Stade Roland Garros]] (clay) [[Paris]], [[France]]
==Awards== '''Associated Press Athlete of the Year''' * Inauguration of the ''Athlete of the Year'' award in the United States by the Associated Press (AP). The AP offers a male and a female athlete of the year award to either a professional or amateur athlete, the awards being voted on annually by a panel of AP sports editors from across the United States. The first winners are: * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Male Athlete of the Year]] – [[Pepper Martin]] (baseball) * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Female Athlete of the Year]] – [[Helene Madison]] (swimming)
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1901 – 1950}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1931 in sports| ]]

{{Infobox civilian attack | title = 2009 Malmö riot | image = File:Mercedes sprint-polisbuss.JPG | caption = Police vans monitoring a section of the wider protests. | location = [[Malmö]], [[Sweden]] | coordinates = | date = 7 March 2009 | type = [[Riot]] | injuries = | perps = 100 detained, 10 arrested, 18 put on trial | weapons = stones, fireworks, paint bombs | numparts = '''Directly involved:''' 200–300
'''Protesters:''' 6,000–7,000 | numpart = | dfens = Malmö police department
Danish riot vehicle support | dfen = }} The '''2009 Malmö Davis Cup riots''' were anti-[[Israel]] riots in the Swedish city of [[Malmö]] against a [[Davis Cup]] tennis match [[2009 Davis Cup World Group#Sweden vs. Israel|between Sweden and Israel]] on 7 March 2009.{{Cite news|title=Anti-Israel protest staged at Sweden tennis match|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-sweden-davis-protests-idUSTRE5261R220090307|publisher=Reuters|date=7 March 2009}}{{Cite news|title=Anti-Israel protest turns violent|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/europe/2009/03/200937141836935467.html|work=Al Jazeera|date=7 March 2009}} ==Background== In February, the tennis match had been decided by Malmö's [[Red-Greens (Sweden)|red-green]] city coalition to be closed to the public, a decision that was heavily criticised by the [[International Tennis Federation]] (ITF).{{Cite news|title=Sweden-Israel Davis Cup to go ahead without public|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/24/sports/24iht-tennisdavis24.20403874.html|work=The New York Times|date=24 February 2009}}{{Cite news|first=Owen|last=Gibson|title=Fans banned from Israel's Davis cup tie |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2009/feb/28/tennis-israel-gaza-davis-cup|work=The Guardian|date=28 February 2009}} The Mayor of Malmö, [[Ilmar Reepalu]] personally said he thought the game should not be played at all, and the decision was thus considered to be more politically motivated than out of security concerns.{{Cite news|title=Davis Cup Double Fault: Israel-Sweden Fan Lockout Stirs Controversy|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/davis-cup-double-fault-israel-sweden-fan-lockout-stirs-controversy-a-611738.html|work=Der Spiegel|date=6 March 2009}} ==Riots== In anticipation of protests around 1,000 police officers sanctioned off a large area around the Baltic Hall tennis stadium to keep protesters and rioters away. A reported 170 truck loads of pavement stones were transported out of the area before the protests, and three schools were closed.{{Cite news|first=Ole|last=Rothenborg|title=Stenhögar kan stoppa polisinsatsen|url=http://www.dn.se/nyheter/sverige/stenhogar-kan-stoppa-polisinsatsen/|work=Dagens Nyheter|date=4 March 2009|language=Swedish}} In addition, for the first time in history, riot vehicles were brought in from [[Denmark]].{{Cite news|first=Jacob|last=Lund|title=Frykter sammenstøt i Sverige|url=http://www.vg.no/nyheter/utenriks/sverige/frykter-sammenstoet-i-sverige/a/551211/|work=Verdens Gang|date=7 March 2009|language=Norwegian}} The match was initially met with protest of around 6,000 to 7,000 anti-Israel demonstrators, with speeches held by the leader of the [[Left Party (Sweden)|Left Party]], [[Lars Ohly]], who while wearing a Palestinian scarf was seen holding a map of Palestine with Israel eradicated.{{Cite news|first=Karl-Johan|last=Karlsson|title=Här raderar Lars Ohly Israel|url=http://www.expressen.se/nyheter/har-raderar-lars-ohly-israel/|work=Expressen|date=27 February 2010|language=Swedish}}{{Cite news|title=Demonstranterna till attack mot polisen i Malmö|url=http://www.expressen.se/kvp/demonstranterna-till-attack-mot-polisen-i-malmo/|publisher=Expressen/TT|date=7 March 2009|language=Swedish}} The demonstrators were joined by several hundred militants of which around 200 to 300 began attacking police with stones, fireworks and paint bombs.{{Cite news|first=Pål|last=Stokka|title=Anti-israelsk demonstrasjon sporet av i Malmø|url=http://www.dagbladet.no/2009/03/07/nyheter/utenriks/sverige/5181651/?www=1|work=Dagbladet|date=7 March 2009|language=Norwegian}} The anti-Israel rioters included [[Antifascistisk Aktion|AFA]] [[Anti-fascism|anti-fascists]], militant [[Islamism|Islamists]], organised [[Neo-Nazism|neo-Nazis]],{{Cite news|first1=Linda|last1=Hjertén|first2=Per-Ola|last2=Ohlsson|title=100 omhändertagna efter demonstrationen|url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/nyheter/article11689300.ab|work=Aftonbladet|language=Swedish|date=7 March 2009}}{{Cite news|title=Godmorgon, världen!: Söndag 8 mars|url=https://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=438&artikel=2682135|publisher=Sveriges Radio|date=6 March 2009|language=Swedish}}{{Cite news|first=David Nannini|last=Nilsson|title=Nazister väntas till tennismatch|url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/nyheter/article11685560.ab|work=Aftonbladet|date=5 March 2009|language=Swedish}}{{Cite news|first=Daniel|last=Poohl|title=Nazister i demonstration mot Davis Cup-match|url=http://expo.se/2009/nazister-i-demonstration-mot-davis-cup-match_2482.html|publisher=Expo|date=5 March 2009|language=Swedish}} as well as activists from neighbouring countries.{{Cite news|first=Richard|last=Lööf|title=SVT:s Richard Lööf rapporterar: "Malmö sämsta tänkbara för högriskmatch"|url=http://www.svt.se/nyheter/inrikes/svt-s-richard-loof-rapporterar-malmo-samsta-tankbara-for-hogriskmatch|publisher=SVT|date=6 March 2009|language=Swedish}}{{Cite news|first=Kenan|last=Habul|title=De vill göra allt för att stoppa matchen|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/malmo/de-vill-gora-allt-for-att-stoppa-matchen/|work=Sydsvenskan|date=7 March 2009|language=Swedish}} Police eventually detained around 100 rioters, arresting ten.{{Cite news|title=Swedish teen jailed for Davis Cup protest|url=http://www.jta.org/2009/04/29/news-opinion/world/swedish-teen-jailed-for-davis-cup-protest|publisher=JTA|date=29 April 2009}} An additional eighteen rioters were later identified and put on trial for their part in the riots,{{Cite web|title=Polis angreps av autonoma aktivister vid Davis Cup-match|url=http://www.sakerhetspolisen.se/publikationer/fallstudier-och-artiklar-fran-arsbocker/politisk-extremism/-polis-angreps-av-autonoma-aktivister-vid-davis-cup-match.html|publisher=[[Swedish Security Service]]|language=Swedish|accessdate=10 February 2016}} with several convictions.{{Cite news|first=Daniel|last=Persson|title=Fängelse för tenniskravaller|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/malmo/fangelse-for-tenniskravaller/|work=Sydsvenskan|date=29 April 2009|language=Swedish}}{{Cite news|title=Fortsatt rättegång om tennisbråk|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/malmo/fortsatt-rattegang-om-tennisbrak/|publisher=Sydsvenskan/TT|date=2 June 2009|language=Swedish}}{{Cite news|first=Mikael|last=Funke|title=Fängelse efter tenniskravaller|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/malmo/fangelse-efter-tenniskravaller/|work=Sydsvenskan|date=25 February 2010|language=Swedish}}{{Cite news|first=Joakim|last=Palmkvist|title=Tre tonåringar dömda för Davis Cup-kravaller|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/malmo/tre-tonaringar-domda-for-davis-cup-kravaller/|date=10 September 2010|language=Swedish}} ==Aftermath== The decision to close the tennis match to the public resulted in Malmö being banned from hosting tennis matches by the ITF for five years.{{Cite news|title=Sweden punished for Israel Davis Cup lockout|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/tennis/daviscup/5095836/Sweden-punished-for-Israel-Davis-Cup-lockout.html|work=The Telegraph|date=2 April 2009}} In addition to having to provide $15,000 in minimum gate receipts for the match, the Swedish Tennis Association was fined an additional $25,000. The [[Swedish Tennis Association]] responded by issuing penalties to Malmö mayor Ilmar Reepalu for his involvement in the event.{{Cite news|first=Federico|last=Moreno|title=Tennisförbundet skickar ny nota till Reepalu|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/malmo/tennisforbundet-skickar-ny-nota-till-reepalu/|work=Sydsvenskan|date=21 April 2010|language=Swedish}} The protest and riots led to accusations of [[antisemitism]] in Sweden.{{Cite news|title=Sverige anklagas för antisemitism|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/malmo/sverige-anklagas-for-antisemitism/|publisher=Sydsvenskan/TT|date=9 March 2009|language=Swedish}}{{Cite news|first=Anna|last=Ekström|title="Politiker måste agera mot antisemitism"|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/opinion/aktuella-fragor/politiker-maste-agera-mot-antisemitism/|publisher=Sydsvenskan|date=14 March 2009|language=Swedish}} Swedish history professor [[Kristian Gerner]] described the situation as "the worst crisis for Jews in Sweden since the Second World War." A 2012 European Men's Handball Championship [[2012 European Men's Handball Championship qualification#Group 4|qualifier between Sweden and Israel]] set to be played in [[Karlskrona]] in June 2011 raised concerns due to the riots, and was considered to be moved to another location by Swedish sports authorities.{{Cite news|title=Oro i Karlskrona för nya kravaller|url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/sportbladet/handboll/article12425388.ab|publisher=Aftonbladet/TT|language=Swedish}}{{Cite news|title=Politiker rädda för Israelkravaller|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/sport/handboll/politiker-radda-for-israelkravaller/|publisher=Sydsvenskan/TT|date=21 April 2010|language=Swedish}} The match was played as scheduled, with a minor anti-Israel demonstration being held.{{Cite news|title=Sweden-Israel Handball Game Sparks anti-Israel Protests|url=http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/sweden-israel-handball-game-sparks-anti-israel-protests-1.367327|work=The Associated Press and Anna Ekström|publisher=Haaretz|date=13 June 2011}} ==See also== * [[Båstad riots]] * [[2008–09 Oslo riots]] * [[2008 Malmo riots]] * [[Malmö Synagogue#Attacks|2010 & 2012 Malmö synagogue arson attacks]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Malmo Davis Cup riots}} [[Category:2009 Davis Cup]] [[Category:2009 in Sweden]] [[Category:2009 riots]] [[Category:2009 in tennis]] [[Category:Riots and civil disorder in Sweden]] [[Category:Sports riots]] [[Category:Political riots]] [[Category:2009 crimes in Sweden]] [[Category:Gaza War (2008–09)]] [[Category:Antisemitic attacks and incidents]] [[Category:Anti-Zionism in Sweden]] [[Category:Islamism in Sweden]] [[Category:Nazism in Sweden]] [[Category:Left Party (Sweden)]] [[Category:Israel–Sweden relations]] [[Category:Politics and sports]] [[Category:March 2009 events in Europe]] [[Category:2000s in Malmö]] [[Category:Antisemitism in Sweden]] [[Category:2009 Davis Cup Europe/Africa Zone]]

[[File:Against Chess Olympiad 1976 Tripoli.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Official logo and stamps of the Olympiad]] The '''Against Chess Olympiad''' ({{Lang-ar|الأولمبياد الضَاد الشطرنج}} ''al-Awlambayād aḍ-ḍādi ash-Shatranji''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.ie/search?q=%22against+chess+olympiad%22&rlz=1C1CHFX_en-GBIE647IE647&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjGxYHn3aLUAhXEIMAKHYDXAVgQ_AUICigB&biw=887&bih=734#imgrc=aKO0FDZHNSfe1M:|title="against chess olympiad" - Google Search|website=www.google.ie}}</ref>) was arranged as an alternative to the official [[22nd Chess Olympiad|22nd]] [[Chess Olympiad]], held in [[Haifa]], [[Israel]], almost simultaneously. This unofficial Olympiad took place in [[Tripoli]], [[Libyan Arab Republic]] from October 24 to November 15, 1976.
==Background==
When [[FIDE]] decided to award the hosting of the 1976 Olympiad to Israel, it caused considerable controversy, as several countries, including the Soviet Union and all of the Arab nations, did not recognize the state of Israel. After FIDE refused to change the venue, the Soviet team boycotted the tournament in Haifa in protest, as did all the Soviet satellite states in the Eastern Bloc, and the Arab member nations of FIDE.
The Arab nations held their own Olympiad in Tripoli at the same time as the official one. In the promotion material, this event was called the ''Against Israel Olympiad'', but it has later become known by the politically less volatile name ''Against Chess Olympiad''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://allermann.blogspot.ie/2014/08/the-against-chess-olympiad.html|title=The Against Chess Olympiad|website=allermann.blogspot.ie}}</ref>
While the unofficial Tripoli Olympiad was a highly charged political event, the actual chess played was on quite a different level. None of the major chess nations, Eastern or Western, came to Libya, meaning the field consisted of the Arab states, a number of minor chess nations, and some that were not members of FIDE at the time. No [[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmasters]] were present, and very few [[International Master]]s attended.
The Philippines, Italy, and Uruguay were the only nations to send teams to both Olympiads, and none of them were able to win any medals at either event.
==Results==
Thirty-four teams played a 13-round [[Swiss system tournament]]. In a somewhat surprising outcome, the completely unknown Salvadoran team, which included 17-year-old talent [[Boris Pineda]], took home the gold medals. Silver and bronze went to Tunisia and Pakistan, respectively.

Grimaldi, Infante, Camacho, Pineda, Velásquez''' |- | style="background:silver;"|2 || {{flagcountry|TUN|1959}} || 36 || IM Bouaziz, IM Belkadi, Drira, Sbia |- | style="background:#cc9966;"|3 || {{PAK}} || 34½ || IM Farooqi, Ali, Ahmad, Mirza, Mohiuddin, Mazhar Hussain |} :{| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" ! # !! {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}}
The '''America's Polo Cup''' was a [[polo]] event held annually in the United States of America from 2007 to 2010, but was declared bankrupt on September 13, 2010.<ref name="nydailynews.com">{{cite news| url=http://www.nydailynews.com/gossip/2010/10/03/2010-10-03_wh_crashers_biz_goes_belly_up.html | location=New York | work=Daily News | title=Virginia girl found eating herself in cage in mobile home; parents Brian and Shannon Gore charged | date=October 3, 2010}}</ref> The event was organized by [[Tareq Salahi|Tareq]] and [[Michaele Salahi]], with varying degrees of support from sponsors. Because the match was unsanctioned by the [[Federation of International Polo]], it was largely considered a spectator event. The event attracted controversy because financial issues surrounding the event, including allegations of, nonpayment of vendors, charity funding issues, and sponsors' names and marks being used without their consent.
==History==
===2007=== On May 12, the United Kingdom defeated America 7-3 at [[Morven Park]] in [[Leesburg, Virginia]].
===2008=== America defeated Italy 6-2 at Morven Park in Leesburg, Virginia.
===2009=== On May 9 America defeated Australia 4-2 at the [[Capitol Polo Club]] in [[Poolesville, Maryland]].
===2010=== The 2010 America's Polo Cup match took place on June 12 on the [[National Mall]] in Washington, D.C., with teams announced as United States and India.<ref name="Washington Post">{{Cite news|last=Tucker|first=Neely|date=June 13, 2010|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/06/12/AR2010061204092.html|title=White House crashers Tareq and Michaele Salahi hold polo event on the Mall|work=Washington Post |publisher=The Washington Post Company|location=Washington, D.C.|page=C.5|accessdate=June 15, 2010}}</ref> The advertised ticket price for the event was $95 per person.<ref name="Washington Post" /> The event had an attendance of about 250 people, with food from [[Popeyes Louisiana Kitchen]].<ref name="Washington Post" /> Reports of the event stated that the players who represented India were actually of Pakistani origin and were from Florida.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.overoll.com/Content/White-House-crashers-Tareq-and-Michaele-Salahi-hold-polo-event-on-the-Mall-/2010/6/13/267201.news |title=White House crashers Tareq and Michaele Salahi hold polo event on the Mall |quote=Polo players representing India, who say they are actually of Pakistani origin and are from Florida, pose for a picture. |work=Fashion |publisher=OverOll.com |date=June 13, 2010 |accessdate=August 30, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100917180411/http://www.overoll.com/Content/White-House-crashers-Tareq-and-Michaele-Salahi-hold-polo-event-on-the-Mall-/2010/6/13/267201.news |archivedate=September 17, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/pagesix/crashers_miss_the_old_days_8La0s8npgjiz4otx0RBteO?CMP=OTC-rss&FEEDNAME=|title=White House gatecrashers miss the 'old days'|work=New York Post|publisher=NYP Holdings, Inc.|date=August 17, 2010|accessdate=August 30, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100903035955/http://www.nypost.com/p/pagesix/crashers_miss_the_old_days_8La0s8npgjiz4otx0RBteO?CMP=OTC-rss&FEEDNAME=| archivedate= September 3, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> A spokesman for the [[Embassy of India, Washington, D.C.|Embassy of India]] stated that neither the Embassy nor the [[government of India]] had any association with the event.<ref name="Washington Post" />
The event's website reportedly identified an Indian company, [[Kingfisher (beer)|Kingfisher Beer]], as a sponsor.<ref name="Washington Post" /> However, Kingfishers' chief executive denied that the company had sponsored the event.<ref name="Washington Post" /> Yashpal Singh, the president and chief executive of [[Mendocino Brewing Company]], Kingfisher's parent company, reportedly stated, "We are not sponsoring this event and have informed the people managing this event of that, .... We have sent legal notices to this effect, and he keeps on advertising us as a sponsor. I don't know what world he's living in."<ref name="Washington Post" />
On September 13, 2010, the business "America's Polo Cup Inc." filed for [[Chapter 7, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 7 bankruptcy]].<ref name="nydailynews.com"/>
==Controversy== Allegations of fraud over the past few years has caused a number of organizations to withdraw sponsorship. In 2009, [[Land Rover]] terminated its sponsorship after a charity created by the Salahis was put under investigation by the Virginia Office of Consumer Affairs. The organization, [[Journey for the Cure]], solicited donations of cash or auction items as part of their mission to support science grants and other funding for cures of [[multiple sclerosis]] and cancer but was never incorporated as a [[501(c)]].<ref>{{Cite news|last=Ryan|first=Kiki|last2=Dufor|first2=Jeff|url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/politics/blogs/yeas-and-nays/Polo-impresarios-under-fire-for-allegedly-charitable-charity-46245897.html|title=Polo impresario under fire for 'allegedly charitable' charity|work=The Examiner|place=Washington, D.C.|publisher=washingtonexaminer.com|date=May 28, 2009|accessdate=September 2, 2010}}</ref> In 2010, the Indian [[Embassy]], Land Rover, [[Ritz Carlton]], and the [[St. Regis Hotels]] terminated their sponsorship after the Sahali's [[2009 U.S. state dinner security breaches|White House gatecrashing incident]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/indian-embassy-cuts-ties-with-gatecrashing-couple/106392-2.html|title=Indian Embassy cuts ties with gatecrashing couple|work=IBN Live: A Network 18 Venture|place=India|publisher=IBN Live.com|date=December 3, 2009|accessdate=September 2, 2010}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.americaspolocup.com America's Polo Cup Official Website]
[[Category:Fraud in the United States]] [[Category:Polo competitions in the United States]] [[Category:Sports trophies and awards]] [[Category:National Mall]] [[Category:Culture of Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Annual sporting events in the United States]]

{{hatnote|For the sport comprising cross country, road running and track and field, see [[Sport of athletics]]. For other uses, see [[Athletics (disambiguation)]].}} '''Athletics''' is a term encompassing the human [[competition|competitive]] [[sports]] and [[game]]s requiring physical skill, and the systems of training that prepare [[Sportsperson|athletes]] for competition performance.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | chapter-url=http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/12495?rskey=WMZWDf&result=20&isAdvanced=true#eid35304975 | chapter = Athletics | title=[[Oxford English Dictionary]] | publisher=Oxford University Press | edition=3rd | date=December 2013 | accessdate = 9 March 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.coastal-performance.com/2010/10/10/coastal-performance-principles-athletic-movement-skills/ |title=Archived copy, Athletic Movement Skills |accessdate=2011-06-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326031831/http://www.coastal-performance.com/2010/10/10/coastal-performance-principles-athletic-movement-skills/ |archivedate=2012-03-26 |df= }}</ref> Athletic sports or contests are competitions which are primarily based on human physical competition, demanding the qualities of [[Endurance|stamina]], [[Physical fitness|fitness]], and [[skill]]. Athletic sports form the bulk of popular sporting activities, with other major forms including [[motorsports]], [[:Category:Precision sports|precision sports]], extreme sports and [[animal sports]].
Athletic contests, as one of the earliest types of sport, are prehistoric and comprised a significant part of the [[Ancient Olympic Games]], along with [[equestrianism|equestrian events]].<ref>Sansone, David (1992). [https://books.google.com/books?id=z6nrLVrlcTcC&printsec=frontcover&dq=athletics%20derivation&source=gbs_slider_thumb#v=onepage&q=athletic%20equestrian&f=false Greek athletics and the genesis of sport, p.72]. University of California Press. {{ISBN|0-520-08095-5}}.</ref> The word "athletic" is derived from the {{lang-grc|άθλος}} (athlos) meaning "contest." Athletic sports became organized in the late 19th century with the formation of organizations such as the [[Amateur Athletic Union]] in the [[United States]] and the [[Union des Sociétés Françaises de Sports Athlétiques]] in [[France]]. The [[Intercollegiate Athletic Association of the United States]] (later the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]]) was established in 1906 to oversee athletic sports at [[college]]-level in the United States, known as [[college athletics]].
Athletics has gained significant importance at educational institutions; talented athletes may gain entry into [[higher education]] through [[athletic scholarship]]s and represent their institutions in [[athletic conference]]s. Since the [[Industrial Revolution]], people in the developed world have adopted an increasingly [[sedentary lifestyle]]. As a result athletics now plays a significant part in providing routine [[physical exercise]]. [[Sports club|Athletic clubs]] worldwide offer athletic training facilities for multitudes of sports and [[game]]s.
{{TOCLimit|2}}
==Etymology== The word athletics is derived from the Greek word "athlos" (ἄθλος), meaning "contest" or "task." The [[Ancient Olympic Games]] were born of war and featured various forms of athletics such as [[running]], [[jumping]], [[boxing]] and [[wrestling]] competitions.
In the modern [[English language]] the term athletics has taken on two distinct meanings. Its meaning in [[Comparison of American and British English|American English]] broadly denotes human physical sports and their respective systems of training. The other, narrower principal meaning of the word comes from [[British English]] and variants within the [[British Commonwealth]]; this meaning of athletics refers solely to the concept of the [[sport of athletics]] (a category of sporting competition that comprises [[track and field]] sports and various forms of [[foot racing]]), rather than physical sport in general.
== Biological factors == [[File:Spalding's official athletic almanac (1800) (14766385385).jpg|thumb|A few athletes]]
Gender and [[human genetics|genetics]] play major roles in athletic [[Somatotype|body types]]. Significantly fewer [[football]] leagues exist for women; however, women have been active in [[martial arts]] for centuries, and sports like [[figure skating]] and [[tennis]] tend to favor women in terms of spectator popularity. [[Basketball]], [[high jump]], and [[volleyball]] favor taller athletes, while [[gymnastics]] and [[wrestling]] favor shorter ones. [[Long-distance track event|Long distance]] runners tend to be thinner, while competitive [[powerlifting|powerlifters]] and [[American football]] players tend to be stockier. Athletic development often begins with athletic parents.<ref name = "Kennedy">{{cite book | author = Kennedy and Guo | title = Jingwu|year=2010 | page = 2 | publisher = Blue Snake Books | isbn = 978-1-58394-242-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/body_and_soul/article2745210.ece | location=London | work=The Times | first=Sadie | last=Gray}}</ref>
Physical conditioning is a primary athletic function for competition. Most often, trainers utilize proven athletic principles to develop athletic qualities; these qualities include coordination, flexibility, precision, power, speed, endurance, balance, awareness efficiency, and timing.<ref name = "Lee">{{cite book | author = Bruce Lee | title = Tao of Jeet Kune Do|year=1975 | page = 43 | publisher = Ohara Publications | isbn = 0-89750-048-2}}</ref> While [[physical strength]] is prized over most other qualities in Western athletics,<ref name = "Feinberg">{{cite book | author = Lisa Feinberg Densmore | title = Ski Faster|year=2000 | page = 22 | publisher = McGraw-Hill | isbn = 0-07-134381-4}}</ref> it is forbidden in the physical conditioning of [[T'ai chi ch'uan]].<ref name = "Thompson">{{cite book | author = Clem W. Thompson | title = Manual of Structural Kinesiology |year=1989 | publisher = Times/Mirror | isbn = 0-8016-5031-3}}</ref><ref name = "Witherell">{{cite book | author = Warren Witherell and David Evrard | title = The Athletic Skier|year=1994 | page = 4 | publisher = The Athletic Skier, Inc.| isbn = 1-55566-117-3}}</ref>
[[Sports medicine]] not only treats injuries with [[medical procedure]], but attempts to prevent problems such as [[Trauma (medicine)|trauma]] and [[Repetitive strain injury|overuse injuries]]. Sports medicine can also include the use of [[massage]], [[glucose test]]ing, [[Rolfing]], [[physical therapy]], and [[Use of performance-enhancing drugs in sport|performance-enhancing drugs]] like caffeine and [[anabolic steroid]]s.
[[Sports nutrition]] is the study and practice of nutrition and diet as they relate to athletic performance. It is concerned with the type and quantity of fluid and food taken by an athlete, and deals with nutrients such as vitamins, minerals, supplements and organic substances such as carbohydrates, proteins and fats. Although an important part of many sports training regimens, it is most intensely applied in strength sports (such as weight lifting and bodybuilding) and endurance sports (for example cycling, running, swimming).
==Training and coaching== Athletes first learn basic movement patterns such as running, stopping, jumping and throwing. Coaches help athletes refine these movements into [[sports training|sport specific]] skills. A skill such as high jumping can then be refined into a competitive technique like the Western roll or the [[Fosbury Flop]]. An individual’s expression of a technique is often called a style; while various competitive [[swimming strokes]] are also called styles. Team sports often develop and practice [[play from scrimmage|plays]] or [[strategy|strategies]] where players carry out specific tasks to coordinate a team effort of attack or defense.
Technical training may also include teaching the [[Regulation of sport|rules and restrictions]] of a sport or game.<ref name = "Balmain">{{cite book | author = Patrick Thias Balmain | title = The Inner Glide|year=2005 | publisher = Destiny Books | isbn = 1-59477-160-X}}</ref>
Elite athletes and teams require high-level coaching. A [[coach (sport)|coach]] is often associated only with an athlete’s technical development; however, a coach will likely play all the roles of mentor, physical trainer, therapist, medical responder, technical trainer and performance facilitator. Coaches may or may not involve [[sportsmanship]] in their program. Coaching typically signifies a quadrennial, ongoing mentorship for athletic development, as opposed to a clinician who might only assist for a short period of time.<ref name = "Scates">{{cite book | author = Allen E. Scates | title = Winning Volleyball|year=1989 | pages = 221–251 | publisher = William C. Brown Publishers | isbn = 978-0-697-06351-9}}</ref>
Not only must coaches be able to teach technical form, but recognize and correct problems with a teams' or an athlete’s technique and conditioning. Recent advancements in video technology can provide accurate biomechanical data to optimize the form, precision, timing, efficiency and power of an athlete’s movements.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.exercisephysiologists.com/BiomechanicalCONCEPTS/index.html |title=Archived copy:Basic Concepts in Sports Biomechanics |accessdate=2011-10-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111028063415/http://www.exercisephysiologists.com/BiomechanicalCONCEPTS/index.html |archivedate=2011-10-28 |df= }}</ref>
Critical to a team’s or an athlete’s success is a [[Winning isn't everything; it's the only thing|winning attitude]]. Inherent in the drive to win is the ability to remain relaxed and focused under the pressure of competition. Modern athletic coaches employ the use of [[sports psychology|sports psychologists]] to help athletes organize themselves through visualization,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanderbilt.edu/ans/psychology/health_psychology/mentalimagery.html |title=Archived copy: The Effects of Mental Imagery on Athletic Performance |accessdate=2011-06-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607185835/http://www.vanderbilt.edu/AnS/psychology/health_psychology/mentalimagery.html |archivedate=2011-06-07 |df= }}</ref> relaxation techniques, self-talk, concentration, etc.<ref>http://skinnybulkup.com/think-strong-and-be-strong-psych-yourself-up-for-maximum-performance/</ref>
==Amateurs and professionals== {{multiple image | |width1 = 225 |image1 = 2011 Okemos High School Girls' Water Polo State Championship Team.jpg |width2 = 100 |image2 = TWU Gymnastics (Bars) Amy Winczura (5694030475).jpg |footer = ''Left:'' A U.S. high school girls' [[water polo]] team (with their male coaches in background) posing with their trophy. ''Right:'' A U.S. university girl practising a difficult [[gymnastics]] manoeuvre under the watchful eyes of her coach.}} {{see also|College athletics in the United States|U Sports}} [[Title IX]] of the Education Amendments of 1972 was created to prohibit sex discrimination in education programs that receive (U.S.) federal funding. The original statute made no reference to athletics or athletics programs. From 1972 to 2006, Title IX underwent a series of amendments for gender equity which became high impact on high school and [[College athletics|collegiate athletics]] because it promoted maximum female participation in athletics through equal spending.
[[Professional sports]] are sports in which athletes receive payment for their performance. Professional athletics is seen by some as a contradiction of the central ethos of sport -- [[competition]] performed for its own sake and pure enjoyment rather than as a means of earning a living.
==Organizations== *[[International Olympic Committee]] *[[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] *[[Amateur Athletic Union]] *[[Union des Sociétés Françaises de Sports Athlétiques]] *[[International Association of Athletics Federations]] *[[Chin Woo Athletic Association]] *[[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics]] *[[Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women]]
==See also== {{portal|Sports and games}} * [[Outline of sports]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == {{Commons category|Athletics}} *{{Cite EB1911 |wstitle=Athletic Sports |volume=2 |pages=846–849 |short=y}} *[http://www.athletes-usa.com Athletic Scholarships] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100615184739/http://ncaa.org/wps/portal/ncaahome?WCM_GLOBAL_CONTEXT=%2Fncaa%2Fncaa%2Fabout+the+ncaa%2Fdiversity+and+inclusion%2Fgender+equity+and+title+ix%2Ffacts.html NCAA Title IX Important Facts]

[[File:KayLaurellCalendarPose.jpg|thumb|[[Kay Laurell]] in a "Calendar Girl" type pose, 1910s]] A '''bodystocking''' is a one-piece [[skin-tight garment]] that covers the torso, legs and sometimes the arms of the wearer. It is a [[foundation garment]] or an article of [[lingerie]] usually made from a [[sheer fabric]] similar to that used for [[stockings]] or [[pantyhose]], or from [[fishnet]], [[lace]] or an opaque material, or a variation of these materials.<ref name=voices>{{cite web|url=http://voices.yahoo.com/bodystockings-sexy-lingerie-many-occasions-695889.html|title=Bodystockings: Sexy Lingerie for Many Occasions|accessdate=26 October 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140619123326/http://voices.yahoo.com/bodystockings-sexy-lingerie-many-occasions-695889.html|archivedate=19 June 2014}}</ref> A bodystocking differs from a [[unitard]], which is worn as an outfit or article of clothing, and a [[leotard]], which is used as a practice garment or performance costume for [[acrobatics|acrobats]], [[gymnasts]] and other similar performers. Designed to be revealed, but not to be too revealing, bodystockings may be worn as undergarments by performers such as [[belly dancer]]s and [[exotic dancer]]s.
==Description== Oftentimes body stockings are made of sheer fabric and are worn with or without undergarments such as a [[Brassiere|bra]].<ref name=voices /> Bodystockings normally come in only two sizes, especially when they use stretch material. A body stocking may be worn for the smooth line it gives or because it cannot become untucked from trousers or a skirt. When worn as underwear, it is usually not worn with other underwear. It may be worn with [[panties]] for extra coverage or a bra for extra support. [[Sheer fabric|Sheer]] body stockings are too revealing to be worn alone.
[[File:CSD 2006 Cologne sexy 2.jpg|thumb|A woman wearing a fencenet bodystocking]]
Opaque bodystockings can be worn in place of [[tights]] and a blouse. Bodystockings also come in fishnet, lace and [[satin]], the latter which may just consist of the top portion of the bodystocking, allowing it to be worn underneath a suit jacket to serve as a blouse. These types of bodystockings are also made sheer, enabling the wearer to wear a more revealing outfit coupled with sheer coverage for line smoothing.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/26/magazine/this-spring-s-under-statements.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm |title=February 26, 1989, New York Times article |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=1989-02-26 |accessdate=2012-10-16}}</ref>
Bodystockings are put on through the neck, in a similar technique to putting on a pair of tights: the body and arm sections are rolled down and then the legs are scrunched up like stockings; one would put one foot in and pull the stocking part up, and then the same on the other leg; from the waist, the bodystocking is pulled up over the torso to the chest, and then the arms are scrunched up and put on in same way as the legs; and the garment is then adjusted as required, and any ribbons and fasteners tied.<ref>[http://www.funkybodystockings.co.uk/How-to-Wear-a-Bodystocking_ep_44-1.html How to Wear a Bodystocking]</ref>
Due to its design, and its close-fitting and one-piece aspect, the wearer may have to remove the bodystocking in order to urinate or defecate, but crotchless bodystockings are also available. If a bodystocking is a foundation garment, all the over clothing will also need to be removed.
==History== It is unclear when the first bodystocking was made or when it was first worn.
The first notable occasion, was when American actress [[Adah Isaacs Menken]] wore one in 1861 in the play ''Mazeppa'', based on [[Lord Byron|Byron]]'s "[[Mazeppa (Byron)|Mazeppa]]", in which she played a [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] man who was tied nude to the back of a wild horse by his enemies. In the scene Menken wore a flesh coloured bodystocking to preserve her [[modesty]] while giving the illusion of nudity. The practice created controversy.<ref name="Brooks">Brooks, Daphne A. “Lady Menken’s Secret: Adah Isaacs Menken, Actress Biographies and the Race for Sensation.” ''Legacy'', Volume 15. Number 1. (1998): pages 68-77.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.funkybodystockings.co.uk/History-of-Bodystockings_ep_49-1.html#first |title=History of Bodystockings |publisher=Funky Bodystockings |date= |accessdate=2013-03-31}}</ref>
A body stocking was used in a [[tableau vivant]] style short film ''The Birth of the Pearl'' (1901)<ref>Produced by [[Frederick S. Armitage]] for the [[American Mutoscope and Biograph Company]].</ref> which featured an unnamed long-haired young model wearing a flesh-coloured body stocking in a direct frontal pose<ref name=sexinfilms1>[http://www.filmsite.org/sexinfilms1.html Sex in Cinema: Pre-1920s]</ref> and provided a provocative view of the female body.<ref>[http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/awhhtml/awmi10/d21.html American Women]</ref>
== See also == * [[Zentai]] * [[Bodysuit]]
==References== {{reflist}}
